com.madisp.stupid

Interface ExecContext

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BaseContext, ReflectionContext, StackContext, VarContext

    public interface ExecContext
    A ExecContext facilitates access to the external environment. Implementations may only provide a subset of the functionality (if stubbed, then a NoSuch* exception should be thrown). An Expression that is evaluated with an empty ExecContext will basically be a constant expression - it won't have access to any fields or methods. A good example of a context is the ReflectionContext which binds the context to a specific POJO instance.

    • Method Detail

      • getFieldValue

        java.lang.Object getFieldValue(java.lang.Object root,
                             java.lang.String identifier)
                               throws java.lang.NoSuchFieldException
        Get a field value from the environment.
        Parameters:
        root - The object whose field value is being queried. May be null which semantically means getting a value from the "scope" or ExecContext itself.
        identifier - field identifier
        Returns:
        the Java value of the given field
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchFieldException - if field was not found / getting value is not supported

      • setFieldValue

        java.lang.Object setFieldValue(java.lang.Object root,
                             java.lang.String identifier,
                             java.lang.Object value)
                               throws java.lang.NoSuchFieldException
        Assigns a value to a field in the environment.
        Parameters:
        root - The object whose field value is being set. May be null which semantically means getting a value from the "scope" or ExecContext itself.
        identifier - field identifier
        value - the new value for the field
        Returns:
        if successful, the value itself
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchFieldException - if the field was not found / setting values is not supported

      • callMethod

        java.lang.Object callMethod(java.lang.Object root,
                          java.lang.String identifier,
                          java.lang.Object... args)
                            throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
        Calls a method in the environment.
        Parameters:
        root - The object whose method is being called. May be null.
        identifier - The method name
        args - List of arguments, the types of these will be matched against the methods
        Returns:
        The result of calling {root}.{identifier}({args})
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException - if no method with matching signature was found or calling is not supported

      • apply

        java.lang.Object apply(java.lang.Object base,
                     java.lang.Object[] args)
                       throws java.lang.NoSuchMethodException
        Yield a value with some arguments. Typically used for evaluating Block instances, but in some implementations may also be used to execute SAM (single-access-method) interface. For an example implementation see ReflectionContext
        Parameters:
        base - The object/value to yield
        args - The arguments, if any, to apply
        Returns:
        The result of yielding the base object
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchMethodException

      • getResource

        java.lang.Object getResource(java.lang.String pckg,
                           java.lang.String type,
                           java.lang.String name)
                             throws java.lang.NoSuchFieldException
        Obtain a descriptor for a given resource. The only Android-specific part in stupid. This method was intended to be used for resolving android integer ID's from package-type-name tuplets. It may be reused for other purposes if it makes sense. All implementations in stupid itself currently throw NoSuchFieldException.
        Parameters:
        pckg - The package name of the resource
        type - The type of the resource
        name - The identifier for the resource
        Returns:
        An object describing the resource
        Throws:
        java.lang.NoSuchFieldException - if the resource wasn't found

      • dereference

        java.lang.Object dereference(java.lang.Object object)
        Dereference an object. Usually this means applying .value(this) onto a value until we have a POJO instance. See BaseContext for an implementation.
        Parameters:
        object - The object to dereference. May be null.
        Returns:
        The dereferenced object. May return the same object if it already was dereferenced.

      • getConverter

        Converter getConverter()
        Obtain the type coercion rules.
        Returns:
        the Converter defining the type coercion rules for the environment
